title: Public Roadmap

last_post.content:
Some cool things on the roadmap for future versions of #Mastodon...

Of those in the "In progress" or "planned" camp that I am looking forward to:

➡️ Groups
➡️ Markdown formatting for posts
➡️ Additional Search Syntax
➡️ Letting you add pending follows to Lists
➡️ Add the ability to import lists

And in explore:

➡️ Login with Passkeys
➡️ Quote Posts
➡️ Thread Pagination
➡️ Home feed digest
➡️ On-hover information cards for users
➡️ End-to-end encrypted messages

https://joinmastodon.org/roadmap

title: SoK: On the Impossible Security of Very Large Foundation Models

last_post.content:
On the large AI models, this preprint synthesises what we know so far https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.15259

In short: it is mathematically impossible to have AIs combining the following properties:

1) High number of parameters
2) Robustness to poisoning (e.g. fake data)
3) Privacy-preserving

title: WebKit Features in Safari 16.4

last_post.content:
Huge release for Safari 16.4 🥳 Congrats to the Safari team!

@property support w/CSS typed OM is probably the one I'm most excited about, but there's also so many goodies in this one!

- margin-trim
- :user-invalid/ :user-valid
- font-size-adjust
- :modal
- Relative Color Syntax
- currentColor in color-mix()
- AccentColor keyword
- MQ range syntax
- outline w/border-radius
- loading="lazy" on iframes

https://webkit.org/blog/13966/webkit-features-in-safari-16-4/

title: Clarence Thomas’s Billionaire Benefactor Collects Hitler Artifacts - Washingtonian

last_post.content:
Ugh… this Harlan Crow mess is gonna end up with a whole lot of well-respected people in the social tech community getting exposed for a whole host of weird neolib/cryptocon bullshit, isn't it?

To Recap: It was disclosed today that the American Academy of Arts and Sciences hosted a series of events around the country on "the Future of Democracy," wherein each individual event was coordinated by local staff (fairly common practice), and no one involved raised any alarm when the Dallas team suggested Harlan Crow's museum house.

That is, "Harlan Crow," as in the known ultraconservative mega-donor, and "museum house," as in the massive mansion he has seemingly crammed to the gills with nazi memorabilia placed right alongside *honoured artifacts by and about his american and british conservative heroes*.

And like… If you ever go to the Holocaust Museum, you will see many horrific things, and they will be presented to you in a way that contextualizes their horror and makes you feel and understand in no uncertain terms exactly how terrible it was and is.

But as can you see in the screenshots below from this Washingtonian article (https://www.washingtonian.com/2023/04/07/clarence-thomass-billionaire-benefactor-collects-hitler-artifacts/), this Harlan Crow shit is not that.

But wait! There's more! When the alarm WAS raised by attendees (who Immediately left [but didn't tell anyone in public about it until now so 🙃😬]), the organizers then got DEFENSIVE about the choice and did *Nothing* about it.

So.

Like i said: this is gonna be a drip-drip-dripping MESS.

Ahh well.

*Dusts off the ol' "Ruat Cœlum, Fiat Justia" placard*

title: hubblesite.org/contents/media/...

last_post.content:
The universe is wild.

This streak on a Hubble photo, originally thought to be an imaging glitch, is actually a 200,000 light year trail of new stars formed by the wake of a black hole that was ejected from the galaxy at the top right.

For reference, that streak is about twice the diameter of the Milky Way!

More details: https://hubblesite.org/contents/media/images/2023/010/01GWQ1F36Y4JK6Y4K8AWMZ86AF?news=true

#hubble #blackhole #astronomy

title: Putin's Twitter account resurfaces as Russia comes in from the cold

last_post.content:
Over on the bad site, Twitter has lifted restrictions on Kremlin accounts and is no longer limiting the reach of Kremlin media accounts.

Russian government tweets are appearing in Twitter’s algorithmically-driven “For You” feed for newly created accounts, even when they did not follow them. So Twitter is not just *showing* these Kremlin accounts — it's algorithmically *boosting* them.

https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/2023/04/07/elon-musk-twitter-lifts-restrictions-putin-kremlin-russia/

title: Pluralistic: Everything advertised on social media is overpriced junk (08 Apr 2023) – Pluralistic: Daily links from Cory Doctorow

last_post.content:
Fantastic essay by @pluralistic who for some time has been commenting on the “enshittification” of media.

He points out that the companies that target ads to you on social media probably have worse products. They spend so many resources surveilling their target audience that they have to cut corners on the product and make it more expensive.

It was kind of thrilling to me to ponder that old-fashioned print-style advertising, based on the product’s relevance to the contextual content around it, is cheaper, more effective and puts more control in the hands of media creators than the shit system of having to pay tech gatekeepers to even get your product in front of your customers.

“a privacy law, ad-tech breakups, app-store competition and end-to-end delivery would shatter the power of Big Tech and shift power to users, creative workers and media companies. These are solutions that don't just keep working if Big Tech goes away – they actually hasten that demise! What's more, they work just as well for big companies as they do for independents.”

https://pluralistic.net/2023/04/08/late-stage-sea-monkeys/

title: Twitter has outsized influence, but it doesn’t drive much traffic for most news orgs, a new report says

last_post.content:
I think people need to understand that Twitter is not a major driver of traffic for most news organizations.

The reason why news organizations are on twitter is because reporters and editors are on it, and it's useful as a tool to get in touch with certain types of folks.

News orgs can leave twitter because it's not critical for them.

(see https://www.niemanlab.org/2016/04/twitter-has-outsized-influence-but-it-doesnt-drive-much-traffic-for-most-news-orgs-a-new-report-says/ )

It's RFC 1's 54th birthday! If you were unaware, in 2019 I did a blog-a-day project where I read through and summarized/contextualized each of the first RFCs up through RFC 365.

I even uncovered a lost RFC!

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/pdf/draft-flanagan-rfc32alt-00

title: pixelfed.art

last_post.content:
We're pretty excited about https://pixelfed.art, and building a trusted community of art and artists on Pixelfed.

That being said, we have to shout out the OG art community on the fediverse, https://mastodon.art. They have built a rich and diverse community of artists and use their following to promote them. It's amazing.

We don't see them as competition, quite the opposite, they are family and we encourage all to find the platform that best fits

Embrace artists, wherever they may be ❤️

title: FSW 2023 : Day 3 - Remote Work: the Good, the Bad, the Ugly, and the Way Forward

last_post.content:
What happened to the future of work? My keynote about REMOTE WORK from 2 weeks ago. TL;DR:
1. After 40 years of research into what makes remote work succeed …
2. … the pandemic era was a parade of catastrophic “worst hits”!
3. But our workplaces are broken, so workers don’t want to go “back”
4. Fixing these problems can help us move forward to a better “future of work”

title: The Library of Alexandra

last_post.content:
'This is the story of one woman’s battle against a global network of academic journals that underlie published scientific research. In 2011, Alexandra Elbakyan had just moved home to Kazakhstan after a disappointing few years trying to study neuroscience in the United States when she landed on an internet forum where a bunch of scientists were all looking for the same thing: access to academic journal articles that were behind paywalls. That’s the moment the very simple, but enormously powerful, website called Sci Hub was born'.

Radiolab interview with Alexandra Elbakyan

https://radiolab.org/podcast/library-alexandra

title: AI is going to change politics, and Americans are skeptical about what could happen - Flux

last_post.content:
A new episode of my podcast, Theory of Change is out today.

This one is a detailed conversation with Change Research pollster Stephen Clermont on public opinion of #AI and how it will change politics.

He did a survey and found people aren't confident they can spot AI content, and then he tested them. They couldn't reliably identify #ChatGPT content.

We also discussed deep fakes and bot armies and how anti-democratic forces use them to fake support.

https://flux.community/matthew-sheffield/2023/04/ai-is-going-to-change-politics-and-americans-are-skeptical-about-what-could-happen/
